animalOfTheDay.name: armadillo
facts: Armadillos can hold their breath for up to 6 minutes when crossing water.
Their armor is made of bone covered by horn-like material called scutes.
They always give birth to identical quadruplets from a single egg.
Only three-banded armadillos can roll into a complete ball for protection.

calendar.name: zebu
facts: Zebus have humps storing fat for drought survival – not water.
They sweat insect-repellent oils and tolerate heat better than European cattle.
Their loose skin helps dissipate heat in tropical climates.
Zebu are sacred in India – 330 million gods are said to live in each.

calendar.name: zonkey
facts: Zonkeys are sterile due to mismatched chromosomes.
They inherit donkey calmness with zebra hardiness against diseases.
Zonkeys are zebra-donkey hybrids; stripes typically appear only on legs.
Their bray combines zebra whinny and donkey 'hee-haw'.

calendar.name: aardvark
facts: Aardvarks can eat up to 50,000 ants and termites in a single night.
Their name comes from Afrikaans meaning 'earth pig' though they're not related to pigs.
They have incredibly strong claws that can dig through concrete.
Baby aardvarks are called cubs and stay with their mothers for about 6 months.

calendar.name: alligator
facts: They can survive up to 2-3 years without eating in extreme conditions.
They're one of the few animals that continue growing throughout their entire lives.
Alligators can hold their breath underwater for up to 24 hours.
A mother alligator carries her babies to water in her mouth after they hatch.

calendar.name: anteater
facts: Baby anteaters ride on their mother's back for up to 10 months.
Giant anteaters can consume up to 30,000 ants and termites per day.
They have no teeth but use their sticky 2-foot-long tongues to catch prey.
Their sense of smell is 40 times stronger than humans.

calendar.name: ape
facts: They share 96-99% of their DNA with humans depending on the species.
Great apes can learn and use sign language to communicate with humans.
They recognize themselves in mirrors, showing self-awareness.
Apes make tools and pass knowledge down through generations.

calendar.name: armadillo
facts: Only three-banded armadillos can roll into a complete ball for protection.
Their armor is made of bone covered by horn-like material called scutes.
They always give birth to identical quadruplets from a single egg.
Armadillos can hold their breath for up to 6 minutes when crossing water.

randomAnimals.name: shoebill
facts: Shoebills are solitary and very secretive, often standing motionless for long periods, waiting for prey.
The shoebill is a large wading bird from East Africa, known for its enormous, shoe-shaped beak.
Its beak is used to catch fish, especially in stagnant, swampy waters.
They have gray plumage and are considered one of the most unusual and prehistoric birds in the world.

randomAnimals.name: budgerigar
facts: No facts available.

randomAnimals.name: hamster
facts: They are nocturnal animals, meaning they are most active during the night.
In the wild, hamsters live in burrows that can be up to 3 feet deep.
Hamsters have cheek pouches that can stretch to store food, sometimes as large as their bodies.
Hamsters can run up to 5 miles in a single night on their exercise wheels.
